Description: The Federal Communications Commission's Enforcement Bureau announced a settlement valued in excess of $100 million with Straight Path Communicationsto resolve an investigation of Straight Path's failure to deploy wireless services as required under its FCC spectrum licenses. All but $15 million was suspended on the condition that Straight Path sell its remaining licenses, which it did.

TracFone, the largest prepaid mobile provider in the U.S., agreed to pay $40 million to the Federal Trade Commission to settle charges that it deceived millions of consumers with hollow promises of unlimited data service.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau filed proposed orders in federal courts against Sprint and Verizon which, if approved, would provide $120 million in redress to wireless customers said to have been illegally billed hundreds of millions of dollars in unauthorized third-party charges. The CFPB alleges that the companies operated billing systems that allowed third parties to "cram" unauthorized charges on customers' mobile-phone accounts and ignored complaints about the charges.

The Federal Communications Commission's Enforcement Bureau reached a $7.4 million settlement with Verizon to resolve an investigation into the company's use of personal consumer information for marketing purposes. The Enforcement Bureau's investigation uncovered that Verizon failed to notify approximately two million new customers, on their first invoices or in welcome letters, of their privacy rights, including how to opt out from having their personal information used in marketing campaigns, before the company accessed their personal information to market services to them.

Verizon agreed to a $3.4 million settlement to resolve a Federal Communications Commission investigation into the company's failure to meet its emergency call obligations during a multistate 911 service in 2014.

Description: The U.S. Department of Labor has reached a settlement agreement that resolved litigation with Verizon New York Inc., which stemmed from citations issued to the telecommunications company in March 2012. The department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration issued citations in connection with the fatal electrocution of an employee on Sept. 14, 2011, in Brooklyn. Under the agreement, two repeat violations and one serious violation are affirmed, with a penalty of $147,000, and the telecommunications company will provide enhanced electrical safety training and other safeguards to its New York field technicians who install suspension strand on utility poles that carry power lines.
Agency: Occupational Safety & Health Administration corporate-wide settlements

Description: The Federal Communications Commission's Enforcement Bureau announced that Verizon Wireless agreed to pay $90  million and Sprint Corporation agreed to pay $68 million to settle investigations that revealed the companies billed customers millions of dollars in unauthorized third-party premium text messaging services, a practice called cramming.

The Federal Communications Commission's Enforcement Bureau announced an historic consent decree with Verizon Wireless -- including a record $25 million payment to the U.S. Treasury -- regarding "mystery fees" the company charged its customers over the last several years. In addition to Verizon Wireless's payment to the Treasury, the company agreed to refund a minimum of $52.8 million to approximately 15 million customers and ensure that consumers are no longer charged the fees.

The Federal Communications Commission announced a settlement resolving an investigation into Verizon Wireless's practice of inserting unique identifier headers or so-called supercookies into its customers' mobile Internet traffic without their knowledge or consent.

The FCC's Enforcement Bureau released a $1.25 million consent decree with Verizon Wireless that resolved an investigation into whether the company had fully complied with the FCC's rules requiring licensees of C Block spectrum to allow customers to freely use the devices and applications of their choosing.

Description: Because of the company's bankruptcy filing, the SEC announced that it would modify its settlement with WorldCom Inc. so that a payment of $500 million would be acceptable in place of the previous settlement amount of $1,510,000,000.

The Justice Department announced that the court presiding over WorldCom, Inc.'s bankruptcy petitions approved the company's agreement to pay the government $27 million to settle claims that it defrauded the General Services Administration from 1999 to the present. In addition, MCI was to pay $670,000 in credits to GSA.

Description: MCI agreed to pay $315 million to 15 states and the District of Columbia to resolve tax claims filed in the bankruptcy of WorldCom Inc., which had merged into MCI.
MCI agreed to pay $100,000,000 in settlement of allegations its predecessor WorldCom defrauded the state of taxes.
MCI and AT&T agreed to pay $40,000 and $10,000 respectively in a July 2004 settlement of allegations they violated the federal Telephone Consumer Protection Act with telemarketing calls.

AT&T, MCI Worldcom and Sprint agreed to pay a total of $1.5 million to settle multistate litigation alleging they misled customers on long-distance calling rates. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amount was divided evenly among them.

MCI agreed to pay $8.5 million to resolve state allegations that it routinely engaged in "slamming," or changing long-distance service providers without permission or through deception, and "cramming," which involves billing for add-on services the consumers have not authorized. The investigation also found that the company continued charging consumers after they canceled their MCI service and hid the actual costs of services it advertised.

MCI agreed to pay $75,000 costs and set aside $175,000 for customer refunds in settlement of allegations its marketing for long-distance telephone service was deceptive and misleading, by failing to make clear all the restrictions and additional charges involved.
Do Not Call violation

The New York State Attorney General announced agreements with Verizon, Time Warner Cable, and Sprint to shut down major sources of online child pornography. The three companies agreed to pay a total of $1.125 million to fund additional efforts by the Attorney General's office and the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children to remove child pornography from the Internet.  The announcement did not specify how that amount would be divided among the companies. Here we assume it was split evenly among them.
Verizon agreed to pay $75,000 as part of the settlement of allegations relating to the placement of unauthorized third party charges placed on telephone bills.
improper billing
Verizon agreed to pay more than $1.3 million in settlement of allegations it overcharged the Commonwealth for telecommunications services under a statewide procurement contract.

Verizon agreed to pay more than $800,000 in interest, penalties and costs in settlement of allegations it overcharged numerous cities and towns for telephone services provided under a statewide contract. It had already refunded the $1.5 million alleged overcharged amount.

Company: Verizon Select Services Inc. and Snyder Communications
Description: Verizon and affiliates agreed to pay $3.1 million in settlement of allegations that it engaged in unauthorized long-distance provider switching, known commonly as slamming.

Company: Verizon Service Corp. and Verizon New England
Description: Two Verizon subsidiaries agreed to pay $317,909 in settlement of allegations they failed to pay full Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund contributions.

Verizon Wireless, Cingular Wireless, and Sprint PCS agreed to pay a total of $5 million to settle multistate litigation alleging misleading advertisements and unclear disclosures relating to service agreement terms and wireless coverage areas. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.

Verizon Wireless agreed to pay $16 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it billed customers millions of dollars in unauthorized third-party premium text messaging services, a practice called cramming.  This was part of a larger $90 million settlement involving the Federal Communications Commission; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-verizon-wireless-0

Info Source: McCollum Reaches Multi-Million Dollar Settlement with Verizon Wireless over 'Free' Ringtones, Targeted News Service, June 24, 2009 (via Nexis).

Description: Verizon Wireless agreed to halt the deceptive marketing of its internet usage plans and reimburse $1 million to customers for wrongful account termination nationwide.

Verizon Business, the successor company to WorldCom Inc., paid the Oklahoma Department of Commerce more than $11.7 million to fulfill the terms of its deferred prosecution agreement with the state. The agreement called for the 1,600 new Oklahoma jobs but those positions were not created.
Info Source: Agreement Closes WorldCom Deferred Prosecution, US States News, August 7, 2007 (via Nexis).
Cellular Settlement, City News Service, August 23, 2001 (via Nexis).

Description: The Commission ordered CPSD to retain and supervise consultants to conduct a review of Verizon's operations and practices related to Individual Csse Basis (ICB) contracts and Verizon to reimburse the Commission for the consultants' costs.  The Commission adopted a settlement between Verizon and CPSD under which Verizon will pay $4,836,000 to the state General Fund in satisfaction of any fines or other remedies that could have been sought or imposed for violation of the Public Utilities Code and of Commission rules relating to ICB and express contracts.

In this decision, the Commission approved the settlement agreement between MCI, WorldCom, and MCI WorldCom and CPSD that resolved the Commission'ss investigation into MCI's alleged slamming and cramming activities.  MCI agreed to pay $2.3 million, in addition to credits it has already paid to affected customers. (MCI estimates its past credits to be in excess of $1 million.) The $2.3 million was comprised of up to $1 million in refunds or credits to affected customers and $1.3 million as penalties payable to state General Fund.

Company: Cellco Partnership LLP d/b/a Verizon Wireless
Description: The settlement resolves all issues in this proceeding regarding the Settling Respondents' involvement with the Malibu Canyon Fire in October of 2007.

This decision approves the settlement agreement between the California Public Utilities Commission Safety and Enforcement Division and TracFone Wireless, Inc. The settlement agreement resolves all outstanding issues in this Investigation and related court action concerning TracFone's collection of public purpose program surcharges and user fees on intrastate revenue since 2000 and provides that TracFone shall pay a $10 million penalty.
Notes: The source provides only the year, so the date is listed here as January 1.
